awd_titl_txt: Regulatory networks for integration of catabolism and behavior in a complex chemotaxis system
awd_abstract_narration:
Aromatic compounds are among the most prevalent and persistent pollutants in the environment.  A group of bacteria called the pseudomonads are adept at detecting and degrading aromatics, and hence have potential as agents for the bioremediation of sites contaminated with aromatic compounds.  The aim of this project is to understand how pseudomonads sense, respond and break down aromatic compounds using experimental and computational approaches. This study will contribute to the development of open source modeling software that will be made available to the general scientific community.  The project will also provide interdisciplinary research training to students at the high school, college and postgraduate levels.

While many aspects of bacterial chemotaxis systems are conserved, previous work from this group demonstrated that the aromatic acid chemotaxis system in Pseudomonas putida is different in that it is intricately linked to both uptake and catabolism of aromatic substrates. This project will utilize a newly developed 'phenotype-centric' mathematical algorithm to model the complex integrated gene circuitry controlling aromatic acid chemotaxis, transport and catabolism in P. putida. This systems-level quantitative mathematical modeling strategy will be used in combination with experimental analysis to dissect these interacting phenotypes. The modeling system will be used to predict the complex temporal series of gene expression events that underlie the sophisticated gene circuitry and resulting cellular phenotypes. The study will test the idea that control of inducer production modulates entry of substrates into the cell through the action of additional transporters. The merit of this study lies in its interdisciplinary approach to understanding the complex relationship between genotype and phenotype. This integrated approach to model prediction and experimental testing of a complex biochemical system has broad implications for organisms in complex microbiomes. The quantitative analysis of this complex integrated system will allow for further refinement of the open-source modeling software tool 'System Design Space Toolbox', thereby increasing its utility to the general scientific community for systems and synthetic biology studies.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to develop a detailed understanding of how soil bacteria sense, respond to, and break down chemicals. We studied the model bacterium Pseudomonas putida F1, which is particularly efficient at breaking down aromatic compounds, which are common in soil environments. Pseudomonas putida F1 is also capable of sensing the presence of these chemicals, which bind to specific receptor proteins called methyl-accepting chemotaxis proteins (MCPs). Although the genes that encode MCPs are easily identified based on DNA sequencing, it is currently impossible to predict what chemical(s) an MCP binds based on sequence data alone. As part of our efforts to characterize bacterial sensing of chemicals, we developed a rapid and simple strategy to identify specific chemical(s) detected by MCPs. For this screening method, we generated hybrid receptors that cause a visible color change when they bind to a target chemical. We identified MCP genes in the genomes of bacteria that are known to degrade specific pollutants (e.g., toluene, benzene, naphthalene, biphenyl, nitrotoluenes), as well as MCP genes sequenced from three different contaminated environments. DNA fragments encoding the predicted chemical binding regions of these >200 diverse MCP genes of unknown function were synthesized and used to generate hybrid receptors, which were used to test for chemical binding. We validated the utility of this screening strategy by testing the binding of a series of hybrid receptors to a wide range of both naturally occurring chemicals and toxic chemical pollutants. To date, we identified several receptor proteins that detect various subsets of amino acids and organic acids, and we also found several that detect the toxic chemical naphthalene.

 As part of the project, we developed and optimized a new type of mathematical algorithm to model the complex gene regulation controlling aromatic acid chemotaxis, transport, and catabolism in P. putida. This systems-level quantitative mathematical modeling strategy was used in combination with experimental analysis to dissect the interacting behavioral and metabolic activities of the bacteria. The modeling system was used to predict the complex timing of gene expression events that underlie the sophisticated response to specific chemicals. This integrated approach to model prediction and experimental testing of a complex biochemical system has broad implications for organisms in complex environments. This modeling software tool, called the 'System Design Space Toolbox', is freely-available to the general scientific community for use in systems and synthetic biology studies. The latest version of the Design Space Toolbox (DST3) as well as its application for the analysis of bacterial metabolic pathways are published under https://hub.docker.com/r/savageau/dst3.

We made additional progress towards our goal of understanding bacterial sensing of diverse chemicals by developing a freely available user-friendly computer program, TaxisPy, to track and quantify bacterial movement in response to the presence of chemicals. This software aims to replace challenging and time-consuming assays that are currently used to quantify bacterial chemotaxis. To validate and optimize the new computer program, we analyzed video recordings of bacteria swimming in buffer and in response to varying concentrations of chemicals. The development and validation of TaxisPy, was published and the program is freely available online at (https://hub.docker.com/r/m1vg/tracking_software).

The project resulted in seven peer-reviewed publications, with additional manuscripts in development.

Broader Impacts activities included the development of freely available software that can be used by the scientific community. Public outreach activities included hands-on microbiology demonstrations and the involvement of undergraduate and high school students in research. Two postdoctoral fellows, one graduate student, twelve undergraduate students, and one high school student were involved interdisciplinary laboratory training.
